comments.text:
I think the key question is what qualities are NECESSARY for an living 
thing to evolve intelligence.

If we assumed (and I think it's an incredibly close-minded assumption), 
that intelligent life could only have emerged in situations similar to to 
our own evolution, then it is not unreasonable to assume it might look or 
act like us.

Obviously, the vast majority of life in the universe is going to be nothing 
like us. However, right now we're only concerned with INTELLIGENT life, and 
so the prime factor our reasoning will hinge on isn't the nature of life in 
the universe, but OUR DEFINITION of intelligence.

For example, if we define possession of mechanical technology an important 
part of what constitutes intelligence, it becomes likely that intelligent 
life must have tactile appendages like fingers or tentacles.

If we say sophisticated communication is a requirement, then we can expect 
intelligent life in the universe to have an evolutionary history of living 
in groups of its own kind, like packs, herds, or colonies.

We should expect a WIDE range in the cultural and physiological differences 
between intelligent lifeforms, but I would still say there's a limit.

we're unable to observe an intelligent designer, we can't tell directly. We 
are able to infer based on evidence. Life appears to be meaningless. What

enforced on others as if it's universal, objective.

comments.text:
Kaku did not contradict himself in the least. (And he basically gave you 
the answer and I'll show you why)

With regard to the safecracker and the cop, it is quite simple if you can 
forsee the motives and outcomes of both scenarios. The safecracker isn't 
smarter but he has a plan. The cop is smarter, but he lacks intel. The cop 
simply does not know which safe the safecracker is going to crack. That is 
why Kaku brilliantly used the key word "prediction."

To put it in a linear fashion: consider two dots on a square board, one 
white and the other black; the cop is white and the safecracker black. Now 
put eight letters scattered between them, from A to H, which represents the 
safes. The safecracker is going to crack one of these safes but the cop 
doesn't know which one. For the cop to actually catch the thief he will 
have to predict which is the most likely target; and for the crook to not 
get caught, he will have to predict which safe to rob that cop would least 
expect. In this case, if it were me, I would rob the one closest to the cop 
because he would not expect me to make that move.

This scanario mimics reality because the only reason crooks get caught is 
not because the cops are smarter but due entirely to intel which are 
cameras, alarms and tips that only occure after the fact.

And why would an advanced soceity be lacking in technolgies that are 
essential, such as medicine and military tactics? The 1st world nations are 
not lacking in any of those areas, so a society that is one thousand times 
more advanced than ours won't be either.

Prediction is a form of intelligence and is not the sum of the whole. IQ 
tests don't test intelligence, but all the parts that make up intellect, 
including foresight.

I hope I was helpful.

comments.text:
It is silly to assume that a high-intelligence species would by necessarily 
be peace-loving.  An intelligent animal will have developed as an 
aggressive predator and violence is the most universally applicable 
solution to any problem, like it or no.  Everything about life is 
violent—we consume other life to survive.  Now it is likely that a 
civilization that survives long enough to be space faring will likely have 
gotten a handle on its aggressiveness for reasons of practicality but to 
assume they would “evolve beyond” it as though it were some natural flaw is 
silly wish-thinking that doesn’t reflect the obvious truth of nature.  Life 
is born in, and survives by, struggle.  Alien invasions are unlikely as 
there is nothing to be found on earth that you can’t get more easily out in 
space.  Water is everywhere and a good-sized asteroid will have more 
precious metals in it than has ever been mined on earth in the whole of 
human history.  Biological material itself might be rare depending on how 
common complex ecosystems are but even then it would likely be far easier 
to make it yourself in a controlled and convenient location then go 
mounting huge interstellar expeditions to hunt it down; ESPECIALLY if it is 
rare enough to matter in the first place.

I'm usually a big fan of Michio, but this video was nonsense. The reason 
that aliens in movies share similar values to humans, is because they have 
to be represented within OUR value systems. They've done many aliens that 
did not; just from the Star Trek universe:  The Borg, Q, Macroviruses, 
Ferengi, the giant cloud alien in Voyager, the  alien that Picard met who 
couldn't speak English, the living space ship in TNG, the crystalline 
entity, etc, etc.

Michio clearly doesn't watch enough Star Trek.

As for safe crackers' brains being "better predictors" than the police, 
again, a total fallacy. It's about cost/benefit. Every safe could be made 
thief proof if the police were willing to invest the resources to do so. 
It's not that the thief is better, it's like protecting kids from being 
killed in RTA's. We COULD ensure that NONE ever did, provided we never 
allowed them to ride in cars or go near roads.

This video was incoherent and poorly thought out. Stick to physics Michio.﻿

have the desire to. Do police fail to prevent safe crackers because the 
safe crackers are so brilliant, or because there's a maximum effort that is 
worth while for the value of the safe's contents? Why has fort knox never 
been broken? Because the value of the contents is so great that it 
justifies ANY amount of precautions to protect them.

Famously, Thomas Kuhn said of the relativist reading of his work, "I am not 
a Kuhnian!". This is a horrible misreading of his work which needs to 
die. And we're decoding animal "languages" daily now, so your other quote 
is ridiculously false. Barring new discoveries, it seems like evolution is 
what leads to complex life, and thanks to the principles of entropy it's 
hard to imagine anything else having that power. Kaku's example of the cat 
is also silly- see de Waal's work on morality in animals, yes we know how 
complex animals' inner lives actually are. Although a cat will sometimes 
rub things purely for ownership, your cat (hopefully) rubs you because it 
likes you. It's marking you to share scents, which is how many social 
animals maintain close bonds to friends and family. So yes, your cat 
(probably) does love you, and it is rubbing on you because it likes you. 
Unless your cat is one of those bossy types, and having worked a rescue, 
you certainly see those too.

comments.text:
+Im Tabe Math isn't a language. It's too much a human invention to consider 
everything speaking to us. it's a representation of patterns used by us. 
Our math would be completely different from alien math but would depict the 
same basic patterns and principles. It's only a "universal language' 
because it's something that we can use to understand how the universe 
works. Calling it a language however is just  misleading. It's like calling 
DNA a language. Compare Chinese mathematics with English mathematics. We 
live on the same planet. Good luck communicating ANY message with someone 
who is using just chinese mathematics. Plus, math doesn't communicate 
messages. It just models reality. Just like DNA models the reality of the 
genome, and the origins of species variation. DNA doesn't communicate a 
message no more than the waves communicate a message. It's too much a human 
invention to consider everything speaking to us. Just like clouds don't 
have faces in them, but we see that they do, just like mathematics may seem 
like its a language, it isn't. Most of the time science is counter 
intuitive.

+depletable It's based on observation and biological knowledge. We know

everything within their territory, quite often. We know that the sense of 
smell is extremely important to them.

Early on, when they are just kittens they rely heavily on their sense of 
smell. They know exactly which nipple of their mother is theirs. When they 
go into a new environment, it's extremely scary for them because the scent 
is so foreign to them. At least based on our observations.

When they are especially scared of a foreign smell they will piss on it to 
leave a very distinct smell. So when cats rub up against you, they are 
claiming ownership of you, but at the same time they are also accepting you 
into their environment.

comments.text:
I understand the concept of territory -- which is what the scent marking 
is. Possession does not equal territory, and the concept of, "I own you, 
human" that Kaku mentioned is the contradictory part.

S/N: lol, everyone loves to try and argue and defend people they don't know 
on Youtube, despite truth. It's in a bad way.

But yeah, I know for 100% certainty nobody can claim to know that a cat is 
saying, "I own you" through the act of scent-marking.

That was my entire point. The video is about how we project when thinking 
of aliens, but people do that about animals (which is what Kaku did). And 
it was Kaku that pointed out how we don't even know wtf animals think, so 
it was weird for him to say what he said.

Territory has nothing to do with possession, and no such studies exist that 
profess cats are claiming ownership of a human when scent-marking.

Again -- to make sure I didn't set off weird die-hard fans on Youtube, I 
made sure to preface everything with "I like Kaku" and have even sat on a 
talk of his.

Just because I pointed out a contradiction in what he said shouldn't set 
everyone off to defend the man's honor. Relax. lol

comments.text:
+FDASARO "The evolutionary pressures on non-predators is to avoid 
predators."
And intelligence wouldn't be useful for that?

" Predators don't need to worry as much about being hunted down, so they 
can afford to carry on evolutionary mutations that improve mental 
facilities"

Apex predators you mean. Lesser predators may still be prey themselves. 
Apex predators, however, usually being the biggest predators in an area 
and/ or living in packs, need very high amounts of food, so they are 
occupied with finding that, whereas herbivores often just have to move two 
feet forward to get fresh grass.

Now, if you had said that searching for living prey and learning the 
patterns of your preys behavior requires more intelligence then picking 
leaves, that would at least be an argument.

You know, actually it is because predators are more occupied, that 
necessitates that they have a higher intelligence than their prey, not 
because they are less occupied.


But intelligence is not necessary for survival and reproduction. And given 
that a huge brain cost a lot of resources, it is often just to expensive to 
be viable.
So you need a really good reason to develop high levels of intelligence. 
Social interaction would be such a reason.
The more intelligent a species is, the bigger are the groups individuals of 
this species can sustain. Respectively, the bigger the group is, the more 
intelligent the individuals need to be (excluding hive mind and the like).

In short, a species must have a need to live in large groups to develop a 
high intelligence.

But a species that already is the apex predator wouldn't need to develop 
intelligence to live in (larger) groups, because they are already 
dominating their environment. Living in (larger) groups would actually be 
counter productive, due to the already stated need of high amounts of food.

BTW. our ancestors first developed high levels of intelligence and then 
they became hunters.

top_comment.text:
Sigh... This is so biologically wrong. You may argue that there are SOME 
species that aren't territorial (e.g. plants, and even that's 
questionable), but most are. Because species prone to fighting tend to wipe 
out pacifist ones. It's survival of the fittest, in a nutshell. And, once a 
creature is sufficiently evolved to not have to worry about that, due to 
having domination of its surroundings, those aggressive genes are already 
ingrained. It's just too likely for aggressive creatures, with some sense 
of social nonaggression (ability to cooperate) to take the peak of the 
evolutionary scale, because those two properties are most suitable for 
survival, in any given universe (Except, maybe, one in which aggression 
unconditionally kills the aggressor. In that sort of universe, trolls would 
be the dominant species, due to their ability to cause others to become 
aggressive and hence kill themselves).

With that out of the way, it's equally incorrect to assume aliens are going 
to be more intelligent. They would be more technologically advanced, that's 
true. But better technology isn't higher intelligence. If anything, cavemen 
were several orders of magnitude more intelligent than we are. Because they 
needed that intelligence on-hand to survive, we don't. In fact, large 
portions of humanity are too dumb to live. If anything, an alien race would 
be closer to idiocracy. The majority of them would be spoiled brats who 
inherited a large amount of technology, can operate it very well, but 
haven't a single clue how it works.﻿
top_comment.author: Saar Korren

comments.text:
+JackBauerwashere
The video, and hence, the discussion, is about aliens who might visit 
Earth, or encounter us halfway, so a species without technology is not 
relevant.
Also, even fish develop aggressiveness. It's not a question of 
technological level. On the contrary, by the time a species has the 
technology to not need violence, they already have violence ingrained.

Finding DNA in space wouldn't suggest a common ancestor. It would simply 
suggest that DNA can form naturally, which is what biogenesis suggests 
anyway. It's no more bizarre than finding water in space.

Also, for anything to develop, even if not via DNA, there has to be a 
"search algorithm", since a fully complex thing cannot just pop out of pure 
randomness. Evolution is a search algorithm that tries all available 
possibilities, and discards those that do not work, therefore finding local 
minima. Without DNA, it would simply need a different method to produce 
possibilities.
If you have a different algorithm that can turn the natural randomness of 
the universe into a working intelligent species without a guiding hand, not 
only would I love to hear it, it would probably be enough to earn you a 
Nobel prize in mathematics, computers and/or biology.

While sharing resources, as the human system of trading has proven, is more 
effective, due to the ability to specialize, than gathering resources 
yourself, it is not vital to the point of creating an extinction horizon.

This is similar to how we use violence to apprehend criminals. They would

As for the speculated life, it was a long time ago when I've heard it, so 
finding a link would be difficult. I can mostly give you details. It was 
after some non-Earth-like planet was discovered somewhere, and it was 
speculated that despite being non-Earth-like it could still sustain an 
atmosphere, and hence, life.
Here are the basic environmental details: The planet has some sort of 
rotational lock, so that one half is permanently frozen, while the other 
half is constantly exposed to the sun. At the center of this exposed area 
is a never-ending tornado. I don't quite remember what causes this tornado 
to exist. Something about the planetary rotation? Or the radiation? Not 
sure.
Anyway, the planet lacks some ozone layer, or some other protective field, 
so solar flares hit it with extreme radiation that could kill land animals. 
It was speculated that there would still be sea animals, and amphibious 
animals. Also, there would be plants with large canopies at the top, 
capable of swaying around, sort of like water lilies or something, so as to 
trap as much radiation as possible when it arrives. And finally, it was 
suggested that there could be a carnivore which, in addition to the normal 
facilities, has a large eye on the top of the head or body used to detect 
incoming solar flares. Upon detecting such, the creature would head for 
cover, in a cave or under a tree, to protect itself from the radiation.

This is as much as I can remember. Maybe if you look up some of the 
details, you can find a more complete article on the internet. Of course, 
most of it is purely speculative, or, should I say, an educated guess made 
by people who understand the physical and biological mechanisms at play, 
but can't really say with certainty what would actually happen.

comments.text:
+thenomaic
The thing is, for evolution to happen at all, there needs to be a mechanism 
in which different species emerge on a planet, otherwise there's no reason 
for anything beyond primordial goo to exist.

If such a mechanism exists, and at least one species exists, then mutations 
of said species must also exist. One such mutation may have a "violent 
gene". And without some force to prune out such a mutation, it is likely 
to, instead, prune out the more benign specimen of the same species.

The benign version must therefore have some method of self-protection from 
such mutant versions of itself in order to survive long enough to create 
space flight and reach our planet.
While having a tough enough head to survive the age-old rock-to-the-head 
may work initially, it's a lot easier to find a bigger rock than to evolve 
an even tougher head. And even if a head too tough for any rock could 
emerge, they could just bump heads until someone dies from it. It's a heck 
of a lot easier to destroy something than to protect it.

I am open to the possibility of workable alternative methods for 
maintaining a gene pool in proximity of violent creatures without being 
violent, such as the fast reproduction method. But such alternatives are 
few. And, as I've noted, natural physical protection is not among them.
If you can suggest other such, I'm certainly open to ideas.

But one thing is for certain: Whatever comes to us from amongst the stars 
must at least have the ability to face being attacked by a powerful force, 
and not face extinction as a result.
And that's an ability they must have had for a large chunk of their 
evolutionary process, not something that just popped up along with their 
latest greatest technology.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.text:
+thenomaic
If you go into finer details, like, why we have 2 arms and 10 fingers, or 
why we are a specific size, then yes, it's very tied to our evolutionary 
chain, and the size and climate of our planet. However, I was talking in 
broader terms, like, why we are territorial.

These behavioral patterns have appeared and reappeared before and after 
mass extinction events, in practically all genus. And the simple reason for 
that is that they are not motivated by any specific environment or genetic 
path. They are required for practically any type of creature to exist in 
any universe.

As noted above, the only practical way to avoid the need for violence, and 
the engrained violent instinct that would result from such a need, is to 
out-reproduce any external threats. In a way, this is similar to how flies 
work on our planet. Due to their high reproduction rate, they don't have a 
need to attack other creatures or protect their territory.

You offer a similar suggestion in the form of immortality. However, that 
solution is not workable. It suggests the existence of a truly 
indestructible creature. And that requires the physical impossibility of a 
truly indestructible object. Even diamonds can be cut, and even black holes 
eventually dissipate. Nothing in this universe is completely immune to 
damage. Entropy always wins.

Your second suggestion, a super-intelligent race, does not preclude violent 
behavior. Sure, thanks to our technological advancement, we live a life of 
luxury, without daily struggle against the elements. But this was achieved 
by trampling the environment around us beyond recognition. These 
super-intelligent creatures would necessarily need to, and will, use their 
super-intelligence for purposes that do not involve being at harmony with 
their surroundings.
Sure, they can eventually become so advanced, that very little in the 
universe is an actual threat to them (Except, perhaps, others of their own 
species). But by then they will have spent generations upon generations 
removing everything that did threaten them. And that sort of instinct 
doesn't just up and poof one day. Evolution has a sense of inertia. Those 
destructive instincts would remain.

One possible alternative is actually the non-natural one: A benevolent race 
that was engineered by a superior non-benevolent one. It's not entirely 
farfetched for members of a violent species to prefer engineering a 
non-violent one which would not threaten them. But it would still mean that 
for every such benevolent race, there's a pretty scary morally bankrupt big 
daddy out there.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.text:
+Jeremy Booth
I'm talking about what is, not about desires. Imagine if every last human 
collectively gained "enlightenment", and decided to each live the rest of 
their life seeking knowledge and happiness, while forgoing all physical 
needs and desires. While there may be a chance that all of those people 
will live very happy lives, extinction would arrive within a generation. 
They may prefer it, but nature would not, as they are expelled in favor of 
species that focus on survival and reproduction instead.

Of course, if you believe race continuity is a higher value, you may 
instead opt to optimize reproduction beyond what our instincts dictate, and 
consider this to be "enlightenment", from a point of view. On some level, 
this is a sacrifice of individual happiness in favor of, shall we call it, 
"the greater good".
By contrast, the view that it's okay for the species to become extinct so 
that you can live a full happy life is equally valid, just not maintainable 
on a grander scale (Since you deny any potential descendants the same 
opportunity, and this "way of life" would disappear along with you and your 
species).

Myself, personally, would pick the 1000 years, but only because that's part 
of my, shall we call it, "faith". Or perhaps a better word is "ideology". 
Unless that misery comes from tolerating an undesirable, in which case I 
would pick removing the undesirable even at the potential cost of life. But 
that's just my personal way of life, which I would not so much as recommend 
to others.

comments.text:
+Jeremy Booth
Your initial premise is so right, that it almost literally (almost) hurts 
me that your conclusion is so wrong. Especially since you had successfully 
proven me wrong.

I'll admit I hadn't considered this possibility. A species can survive and 
even thrive without having to resort to violence, simply by out-reproducing 
any external harmful force. I don't know if this is what the people above 
would call "enlightened" but it's a workable solution: A species completely 
devoid of violent instincts, yet focused on reproducing, and, by proxy, to 
positive interaction with others.

The down side is that such a species would actually be WORSE for us than 
the violent conqueror. Arriving in massive amounts, they would act like 
locust, bringing a message of peace, while, at the same time, consuming our 
resources at a rapid rate. While attempts to eliminate them would be met 
with little to no resistance, they would remain futile, as their sheer 
numbers would be simply unmanageable. And, when they arrive on our planet 
they would be interested in only two things: Testing the possibility of 
coupling with members of our species, and attempting to get resources, 
having exhausted those of their own home planet, and every other planet in 
their path.

And the best part of it is, we'll be the ones who look like the evil 
violent race, when we try to do some "population control" on the incoming 
peaceful horde.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.text:

reproduction. Considering that you could produce a virtually unlimited 
number of offspring, your drive to reproduce can override you drive to 
survive. Your drive to survive can override your drive to be happy. Since 
we know that we are held hostage by our flesh and that we all experience a

with the constant idea that you and your species are damned if you fail to 
survive best, you will live in a state of fear and strife. That's just 
wrong to do to yourself not to mention the other people you effect. And 
"wrong" is a valid notion if you keep your perspective at "eye-level" and 
not try to think beyond your means. If you truly care for the future of 
your species you will consider the QUALITY of their life not QUANTITY.

few errants.

the moment they encounter a violent person.

+WormholeJim I am the first to admit that i am not very knowledgable about 
these things that you explained, although i get the gist of it. I'm not

psychological time. The time that basically the whole of humanity lives by. 
The time that tells us that the past and the future have existence of their 
own, independent of our minds. The time that we use to build our identities 
from (past) and that we are trying to reach for the rest of our lives (the 
future).

I understand that you might say that i'm leaning towards philosophy. 
However, philosophy doesn't interest me one bit. I don't care for complex 
theories about how reality works. I'm only interested in what my direct 
experience is. And my direct experience is that it is always now. This 
present moment is not one infinitely small fragment of time lodged between 
the past and the future, but that which is always the same. It is so 
obvious and maybe that is why no one seems to notice it, yet it is always 
here. Only when the mind interprets this now, it divides it up into past, 
present and future. In other words, the mind creates (psychological) time. 
It seems to me that this is a major misunderstanding.

Thank you for your understanding and polite post by the way. Most people 
strangely enough get mad when i talk about this.
comments.author: Sydebern

comments.text:
+Sydebern [Sydebern wrote] "I just simply wonder where this so called time 
is to be found? Because where i am, it is always now. The 'past' only 
exists in my head as thought and so does the 'future'. Just because almost 
the entire human population believes that the 'past' is a real thing and 
the 'future' will arrive someday, doesn't make it less ridiculous."

Time is found in space. Or rather, it is found in the relation of one 
moving object in space compared to another moving object in space. Time, 
then is a function of space, and not a dimension in the way of dimensions 
as we normally think about them (trajectories of movement within Space, ie 
3D Space).

That time exists as such is easy to establish. Simply observe an object 
move from 'A' to 'B', measure the distance travelled, then calculate the 
speed of the object by comparing the distance with how long it took the 
object to travel it. And thus one can imagine time being stopped locally 
within a black hole, or in regions of space where temperatures equals 
absolute zero. In these Places there are no movement, and so there are no 
(internal) time. There is still outside-time, obviously, as time is 
a general function of the universe in it's entirety. 

Your argument is valid, since it touches on the notion that time 
should have dimensional properties - ie the fourth dimension - and it does 
not. As you very correctly point out to other posters in this thread, one 
cannot travel in time except by virtue of the mind (remembering past and 
projecting future). But your argument is also very much philosofical, since 
you also write off the very real nature of time as being the way to 
accurately express the speed of movement. The notion of past, present and 
future (beyond their applications within natural science as reduced, 
simplified events) are firmly lodged in philosofy.

So, to sum up, time is an integral, defining function of space. Arguing 
that time-epochs does not exists as actual 'places' is only valid inside a 
philosophical discussion. Anywhere else, it simply does not make sense - 
hence the philosofical quagmire;-)
comments.author: WormholeJim

and motor functions". My understanding, which you seem to share, is that 
while the brain is small, the neural network is large enough to support a 
body of that size. However, intelligence requires a lot more than a bunch 
of responsive neurons. The brain-to-body comparison refers to the central 
processing unit and often disregards the rest of the nervous system. I am 
personally way more interested in emergent systems and epiphenomena. I.e. 
moving beyond *where* the neurons are and figuring out how a very basic 
mechanism like synaptic sensitivity build-up can lead to huge effects like 
memory, when put into a system that employs it millions of times. I am 
convinced that alien brains, should they exist, would show a lot of 
convergent evolution with ours but am equally wary of ruling out the 
possibility that they will exhibit some new, spectacular architecture - 
like multiple, parallel streams of consciousness or more rigid memory 
retrieval.
comments.author: JPM

comments.text:
+JPM well I just thought it would be a good conversation about what 
possible neurostructure dinosaurs would have considering the famous 
comparison of the stegosaurus' brain to the size of a walnut while it 
itself weighs tonnes. My ideas are kind of based on what often is called 
reflexes that are contained probably within the spinal neuro network. for 
example the tests done to show that stepping motions are reflexive while 
the spinal cord is severed to the CNS. In addition there are also 
understood to be neural bundles elsewhere in the body called plexus' or 
ganglions. these are usually seen as a junction and are really common among 
the sympathetic nervous system. Could it be possible these ganglion's and 
plexus were more developed in these super-sized reptiles and included the 
somatic neural system and allowed limited processing with signals to/from 
the CNS proper to allow cohesion and control. In other words was the CNS 
de-centralised with peripheral centres. Maybe that's kooky, but it could be 
a hypothesis
comments.author: mrbishi1000

To be sure, I am not a neurosurgeon and I assure you anything I say is

comments.author: JPM

comments.text:
+JPM I assure you I am not being racist about dinosaurs or any other living 
entity. And I don't want to "shave" anybodies hypothesis. I don't even know 
why you brought up Occam. "What about them?" Well we are told some had very 
small brains for their size. and you did say " it also depends on the brain 
size to body weight ratio, the structure of the brain and the physical 
ability of the animal to sense and act on the world around them." So then, 
my question is, what about dinosaurs? Without using Occam's razor, tell me 
an acceptable hypothesis on intelligence by being more to the point than 
you have. More on the "collection of hundreds if not thousands of factors". 
If not then elucidate in a better way so I can get what you mean. please. I 
actually would like to know what you think.
comments.author: mrbishi1000

comments.text:
+mrbishi1000 What about them?

To reiterate: Brain size certainly has some correlation with intelligence, 
particularly when compared to the size of the body and expected brain size 
in similar species. HOWEVER, there are myriad other factors involved, which 
surpass just size. Brain structure, used neural pathways, pruning, 
cogitative optimization and the depth, control, and number of available 
senses and motor functions - All of these would have as much (if not more) 
of an effect on intelligence. There is a lot of misinformation and 
misunderstanding of nature vs. nurture which lead to some racist or 
similarly dangerous attitudes but there you have it. Intelligence, like 
"consciousness", is an epiphenomenon - a collection of hundreds if not 
thousands of factors. Oversimplification is just as bad as ignoring Occam's 
razor.

I don't think aliens that may visit us would have been vastly more 
intelligent than us from the onset, but of course they will have had ample 
time to improve it artificially since then (as we will). So what Michio is 
saying is of course still true, they will be vastly more intelligent by the 
time we meet them (given that they are the ones with the initiative and 
technology to make it happen, and not us far far into the future), but I 
think it is important to consider how that gap might not be something fixed 
in stone.

I say that because alien evolution must have been governed by the same 
evolutionary principles that govern ours, and nature does not give anything 
for free. The moment an animal has evolved to be smart enough to begin 
building a civilization, they will do so, and not wait a couple of 100 
millenniums more for a bigger brain to do so. Civilization comes first, 
even bigger brains later.﻿

captions.text:
I love to watch science fiction movies but
I cringe -- I cringe whenever I see a depiction

of the aliens. First of all the aliens speak
perfect English. Not just British English.

They speak perfect American English. And obviously
they're a human inside some kind of monkey

suit. I mean we have Hollywood special effects,
right. So why can't we get better aliens.

And then the aliens think just like us. They're
territorial. They want to conquer. They want

resources. They want -- they see humans as
inferior. But you see, that's only a byproduct

of our evolution. Look at other animals in
the animal kingdom. Some animals are not territorial,

okay. They don't have to conquer. We have
other paradigms in the animal kingdom which

are totally different form the way our brain
is constructed. But when we look at aliens

in the movies we're basically projecting our
own consciousness in aliens. Our fears, our

desires are projected and they are a mirror
of who we are, not a mirror of who they really
are.

For example, if we take a look at a bat or
a dog, the dog's brain is mainly interested

in smells. It's swirling in a universe of
smells while a bat's brain mainly is concentrated

on sonar, on detecting clicks and echoes.
Same thing with the dolphin brain. Their consciousness

is totally different from our consciousness
because they see things differently than us

because of their evolutionary history. For
example when we see a cat and the cat comes

up to us and tries to purr next to us, we
say to ourselves, "Oh, nice cat. The cat is

being affectionate." No. The cat is not being
affectionate. It's simply rubbing his hormones

on you and saying, "I own this human. This
human is mine. I'm marking my territory. This
human feeds me twice a day. I've trained him."

So a cat sees the universe totally different
than we do and yet we impose our thinking

on an alien. Now on the question of intelligence.
If these aliens are more intelligent than

us, how would they be more intelligent? In
the book I say that one of the main ingredients

of intelligence is to predict the future.
The ability to simulate today so we see tomorrow.

And that requires a high level of intelligence
to be able to understand the laws of nature,

the laws of people. What is the most likely
outcome of a future event. That requires intelligence.

If they are more intelligent than us they
will see the future much better than us. They

will see outcomes that we cannot foresee.
They will simulate scenarios that we cannot
even dream of. They can outwit us every time.

Think of a safecracker. A safecracker may
have a low IQ, may have dropped out of elementary

school. But the safecracker can simulate the
future much better than a cop can and that's

why he can rob banks and get away with it.
And so in other words, the criminal mind is

not necessarily stupid because it has low
IQ. It's quite well adapted for what it does.

And what it does is to simulate the future
of a crime. Now think about when we encounter

intelligent life that is more intelligent
than us. They may see the world totally differently.

Their world may be a world of smells, a world
of sounds rather than a world of eyesight

like our brain is constructed. And most important,
they may be able to see the outcome of future

events much better than us. They'll be able
to actually run circles around us because
they see the future.
